title: Federal Police to review all sensitive investigations
text:
"Mr Lawler will provide my office with options and opportunities for intervention and strategies to ensure the AFP is best placed to address sensitive investigations in the future."

Mr Kershaw told estimates he had not seen the front pages of the country's major newspapers, including The Australian Financial Review, which, in an unprecedented show of unity, published heavily redacted images accusing the government of hiding the truth from the public.

"Police independence and freedom of the press are both fundamental pillars that co-exist in our democracy. I strongly believe in these two pillars and this is the approach I intend to make," Mr Kershaw said.

Mr Kershaw, who has been the nation's top cop for 19 days, inherited two high-profile leak investigations into government whistleblowers over national security.

Raids on the home of a News Corporation journalist as well as the ABC's Sydney headquarters in June sparked widespread alarm that press freedom was being eroded.

The government has been under pressure to end what media companies describe as a culture of secrecy, with the industry calling for a raft of changes including broader exemptions for journalists who risk a criminal offence for their reporting on national security issues, and an overhaul of court suppression, defamation and freedom of information laws.

Attorney-General Christian Porter has attempted to ease media outlets concerns that News Corporation reporter Annika Smethurst and ABC journalists Dan Oakes and Sam Clark could be jailed over their reporting by requiring his approval before any prosecutions were launched against them.

However, the government or police are yet to offer a concrete assurance the journalists will not be pursued.
description: The new boss of the Australian Federal Police has ordered a review of how it handles sensitive political investigations including those involving journalists and politicians.
